title: Welcome to Profit Times
text:
Your go-to source for breaking news where money rules the world.

Because pipelines deserve better protection.

Now every lunch comes with a brand sponsorship.


Corporation Discovers New Mineral: Pure Capitalism
Turns out profits can literally be mined.

Meta-profit inception at its finest.

title: Man Starts Fundraising Campaign to Fund Fundraising Campaigns
text:
Man Starts Fundraising Campaign to Fund Fundraising Campaigns
In what may be the most meta fundraising initiative of the decade, local entrepreneur Brad Moneybags launched a campaign to fund future campaigns.
“I realized people love giving money, but only if it’s organized by someone else,” Moneybags explained. “So I’m creating the ultimate fundraising fund.”
Supporters are reportedly impressed by the efficiency and innovation of raising funds to raise more funds—a process some are calling “profit inception.”

title: Local School Sells Naming Rights to Cafeteria
text:
Local School Sells Naming Rights to Cafeteria
In a groundbreaking education-meets-advertising initiative, Lincoln High has sold the naming rights to its cafeteria.
Students now eat lunch under banners proudly sponsored by SnackCorp™, SodaBlast™, and MysteryEnergyDrink™. “We thought it would motivate students to learn,” said the principal. “Who doesn’t want to study when every bite comes with a brand endorsement?”
Parents are reportedly thrilled that their children are being prepared for a corporate future—one lunch at a time.

title: Mayor Turns City Hall into Luxury Hotel
text:
Mayor Turns City Hall into Luxury Hotel
In an unprecedented move blending politics and real estate, the mayor has converted City Hall into a five-star luxury hotel.
Residents are reportedly confused about where to pay their parking tickets, but investors are ecstatic. “We see untapped potential in civic real estate,” said one hotel manager. “Why have a council meeting when you can have a spa day?”
The public is encouraged to book early, especially for the penthouse, formerly the mayor’s office, now offering skyline views and complimentary lobbying advice.

title: Corporation Discovers New Mineral: Pure Capitalism
text:
Corporation Discovers New Mineral: Pure Capitalism
Scientists were stunned when researchers at MegaCorp Labs announced the discovery of a new mineral: Pure Capitalism.
The mineral is reportedly shiny, highly malleable, and incredibly rare—perfect for forging new business ventures and stock portfolios. “We’ve already patented it,” said a spokesperson. “It’s amazing what you can do when the planet is just a resource for profit.”
Environmentalists are unconcerned, citing their limited capacity to compete with billion-dollar marketing campaigns.

title: Standing Rock: Protests Threaten Nation’s Bottom Line
text:
Standing Rock: Protests Threaten Nation’s Bottom Line
STANDING ROCK, ND — Local and national businesses are reportedly “deeply concerned” this week as the Standing Rock protests continue to delay what could have been another record-breaking quarter for corporations. Experts warn that these protests, led by people calling themselves “activists,” are standing in the way of progress, growth, and most importantly, profits.
“Every hour that pipeline construction is stalled, we’re losing money,” said a spokesperson for a company involved in the project. “We understand there’s an environmental impact and some people have feelings, but feelings don’t pay dividends. We just want to make America wealthy again—one oil pipeline at a time.”
Protesters argue that the pipeline threatens water supplies and sacred lands, but corporate leaders maintain that the real tragedy is that delayed construction is bad for business. “We’ve got quarterly reports to worry about,” said another executive. “If the water is safe or if sacred sites are preserved, that’s great, but if it doesn’t fit into a profit margin, we have to reassess our priorities.”
Meanwhile, local communities have been encouraged to “think about the bigger picture,” namely the increased stock value of oil companies and the possibility of shareholders receiving slightly higher bonuses this year. One corporate analyst noted, “We’re just trying to balance the budget here. Protecting water? Important. Protecting profits? Even more important.”
Some economists suggest that the protests might even inspire innovation in the private sector, such as developing pipelines that can carry oil faster or designing shareholder-friendly environmental impact studies. “If these protests have taught us anything, it’s that people are stubborn,” said the analyst. “And we can turn that stubbornness into, well, money.”
As the standoff continues, corporate leaders remain hopeful that eventually, the protests will realize the futility of prioritizing morality over financial gains. Until then, shareholders are urged to stay patient and remember: in the battle between ethics and earnings, earnings always win.
